epigraph.para: We are stuck with technology when what we really want is just stuff that works. How do you recognize something that is still technology? A good clue is if it comes with a manual.

preface.title: Introduction
preface.para: This Manual describes the Underworld Adventures Debugger, an add-on piece of software for Underworld Adventures, the project that tries to recreate the old Ultima[tm] Underworld games on modern operating systems and platforms.

The Underworld Adventures Debugger mainly exists to create custom games using the Underworld Adventures engine and one of the Underworld games as a "template". It helps creating maps, placing objects and critters, writing conversation scripts and debugging Lua scripts that further help to customize the game.
The Manual describes the all features of the Debugger and what you can do with it. It also shows you how you create a new game with it. The conversation script language is described in detail.

section.title: The main debugger window
section.para: The Debugger main window that appears after pressing the debug key (see the Underworld Adventures Manual) consists of several user interface items: The title bar, the menu, the toolbar, the work area and the status bar. The work area can contain windows that show game info and the like.

There are two different type of windows: dockable windows and normal windows. Dockable windows can be docked at every side of the work area, as well as just "floating" in the work area. When the window is docked, it makes the work area smaller. Dockable windows cannot be resized to the whole screen (at least they were not designed as such). Normal windows can be resized in any direction and they can be minimized to an icon or maximized to the whole size of the work area.
